Dainty fine bird....... Orlanào Gibbons Sing we and chant it. While love doth grant it, Fa la la! Not long youth lasteth And old âge hasteth, Now is best leisure, To take our pleasure. Fa ta la! Ail things invite us Now to delight us, Fa la la! Hence care be packing, No mirth be lacking, Let spare no treasure To live in pleasure, Fa la la! Dainty fine bird that art encaged there Alas, how like thine and my fortunes are, Both prisoners be, and both singing thus Strive to please her that hath imprisoned us. Only thus we differ, thou and I, Thou liv’st singing, but I sing and die. 7. Sweet honey-sucking bees John IFilbyc Sweet honey-sucking Bees, why do you still Surteit on Roses, Pinks and Violets, As if the choicest nectar lay in them Wherewith you store your curious cabinets; Ah make you flight to Melisuaviæ’s lips; There may you revel in Ambrosian cheer, Where smiling Roses and sweet Lilies sit, Keeping their spring-tide grâces ail the year. Yet sweet, take heed, ail sweets are hard to get; Sting not her soft lips, oh beware of that, For if one flaming dart come from her eye, Was never dart so sharp, ah then you die! I threshed it with my needle and thread, And a bunch of green . holly and ivery. 1 winnowed it with my handkerchief, Ivy sing ivery. I sent it to mill with a team of great rats, And a bunch of green holly and ivery. The carter bought a curly whip, Ivy sing ivery. The whip did pop, and the waggon did stop And a bunch of green holly and ivery. 11. Wassail Song arr. R. Vaugban MPillianu Wassail, Wassail, ail over the town, Our bread it is white and our aie it is brown, Our bowl it is made of the green maple tree. In the wassail bowl we’ll drink unto thee. Here’s heateth to the ox and to his right eyc, Pray God send our master a good Christmas pie, A good Christmas pie as e’er I did see, In the wassail bowl we’ll drink unto thee. Here’s health to the ox and to his right horn, Pray God send our master a good crop of corn, A good crop of corn as e’er I did see, In the wassail bowl we’ll drink unto thee. Here’s health to the ox and to his long tail, Pray God send our master a good cask of aie, A good cask of aie as e’er I did see, In the wassail bowl we’ll drink unto thee. Come butler, come fill us a bowl of the best, Then I pray that your soul in heaven may rest; But if you do bring us a bowl of the small, May the devil take butler, bowl and ail! Then here’s to the maid in the lily-white smock, Who tripped to the door and slipped back the lock, Who tripped to the door and pulled back the pin For to let these jolly wassailers walk in. DUOS 16. 1 spy Celia............ Henry Purcell I spy Celia; Celia eyes me. I approach her; but she flies me. I pursue; more coy I find her. 1 seem colder; then she’s kinder. Her eyes charm me; ray words move her, She esteems me; and I love her. In not blessing most she blesses, And not possessing, each possesses. Now she blushes, I grow bolder. She would leave me, but I hold her. She grows angry, I appease her. I am redder, then I please her. 17. John, come kiss me now, arr. E.-IV. Naylor Wife. John, come kiss me now, John, come kiss me by-and-by, And make no more ado. Husband. Peace, I’m angry now, Peace, I’m angry at the heart And know not what to do. Wives can faine and wives can flatter, Hâve I not hit them now. When once they begin they still do chatter And so does my wife too. j5. Now of my song I make an end, Lo, here I quit thee now, Ail evil wives to the devil I send Amongst them my wife too. 18. The Three Fairies..... Henri/ Purcell When the cock begins to crow And the embers leave to glow And the owl cries tu-whit tu-whoo, When cricket do sing And mice roam about And midnight bells ring To call the devout, When the lazy lie sleeping And think it no harm Their zeal is so cold And their beds are so warm When the long lazy slut Has not made the parlour clean. No water on the hearth is put, But ail things in disorder seem; Then we trip it round the room And make like bees a drowsy hum, Be she Bessy, Nan or Sue, We make her of another hue And pinch her black and blue. Chain me, chain me, O most fair, Chain me to thee with that hair. 20. The Silver Swan ..... Orlando Gibbon<1 The Silver Swan who, living, had no note, When death approached, unlocked her silent throat, Leaning her breast against the reedy shore, Thus sung her first and last and sung no more. ’Farewell ail joys, O death, come close mine eyes, More geese than swans now live. more fools than wise.” 21. Lure, Falconers !......... John Bennett Hawking for the Héron and Duck. Lure, falconers! give warning to the field. Let fly! let fly! make mounting hérons to yield. Die, fearful ducks, and climb no more so high, The nyas-hawk will kiss the azuré sky. But when our soar-hawks fly and stiff winds blow, Then long too late wc falconers cry ”Hey lo!” 22. Come away, sweet love ’lhomaa Greavc* Come away, sweet love, and play thee Lest grief and care betray thee. Fa la la. Leave off this sad lamenting, And take thy heart’s contenting, The nymphs to sport invite thee, And running in and out delight thee. Fa la la. IMPRIMERIE ORIVET, GENÈVE
